revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{original research|date=December 2014}} {{NPOV language|date=February 2015}} {{Globalize|date=July 2010}} }} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}}
'''Music plagiarism''' is the use or close imitation of another author's music while representing it as one's own original work. [[Plagiarism]] in music now occurs in two contexts—with a ''musical idea'' (that is, a [[melody]] or [[Motif (music)|motif]]) or ''sampling'' (taking a portion of one sound recording and reusing it in a different song). For a legal history of the latter see [[Sampling (music)#Legal issues|sampling]].
==Overview== Any music that follows rules of a [[musical scale]] is limited by the ability to use a small number of notes. All forms of music can be said to include patterns. [[Algorithm]]s (or, at the very least, formal sets of rules) have been used to compose music for centuries; the procedures used to plot voice-leading in Western [[counterpoint]], for example, can often be reduced to algorithmic determinacy.{{Citation needed|date=November 2015}}
For these reasons, accidental or "unconscious" plagiarism is possible. As well, some artists abandon the stigma of plagiarism altogether. Composer [[Dmitri Shostakovich]] perhaps commented sarcastically on the issue of musical plagiarism with his use of "[[We Wish You a Merry Christmas]]," an instantly recognizable tune, in his [[24 Preludes and Fugues (Shostakovich)#Prelude and Fugue No. 15 in D-flat major|Prelude No. 15 in D Flat, Op. 87]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Wolfgang Amadeus Copycat|publisher=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2061711/}}</ref> In some instances, it was also erroneously assumed that songs are still in copyright such as "Happy Birthday to You".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/26/arts/happy-birthday-and-the-money-it-makes.html|title='Happy Birthday' and the Money It Makes|work=The New York Times|date=26 December 1989|accessdate=16 April 2015}}</ref> In 2015, a lawsuit which challenged the copyright, found this was not the case.<ref name=maiduc>{{cite news |url= http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-happy-birthday-song-lawsuit-decision-20150922-story.html |title= 'Happy Birthday' Song Copyright Is Not Valid, Judge Rules |date= September 22, 2015 |first= Christine |last= Mai-Duc |newspaper= Los Angeles Times |access-date= September 29, 2015 }}</ref>
Many songs are in [[public domain]]. For example, the work of [[Robert Johnson]] (1911 – 1938) is public domain in the [[European Union]] because Johnson died more than 70 years ago (1938 + 70). Some songs of [[W.C. Handy]] (1873 – 1958) are public domain in the USA because they were published before 1922 (e.g. "Memphis Blues"), but they are normally not public domain in the European Union until 2028 (1958 + 70). But the "[[Rule of the shorter term]]" (i.e. where copyright law overlaps, the law with the shorter term is upheld) makes them public domain in the states of the European Union.<ref>{{cite web | title=Public Domain Blues Songs | url=http://12bar.de/cms/albums/public-domain-blues-songs/ | date=2014 | accessdate=September 29, 2015 | last=Bicocchi | first=Matteo}}</ref>
According to [[U.S. copyright law]], in the absence of a confession, musicians who accuse others of stealing their work must prove "access"—the alleged plagiarizer must have heard the song—and "similarity"—the songs must share unique musical components.<ref>{{cite web | title=Picking Up What They're Laying Down | work=Gelf magazine | url=http://www.gelfmagazine.com/archives/picking_up_what_theyre_laying_down.php | date=2014 | accessdate=23 November 2008 | last=Conner-Simons | first=Adam}}</ref> though it is difficult to come to a definition of what is "similarity".
===Folk tradition=== The issue of plagiarism in folk music is problematic as copying and not crediting songs was common. Noted blues author and producer [[Robert Palmer (writer)|Robert Palmer]] states "It is the custom, in blues music, for a singer to borrow verses from contemporary sources, both oral and recorded, add his own tune and/or arrangement, and call the song his own".<ref>{{cite book| title=In the Houses of the Holy: Led Zeppelin and the Power of Rock Music| year=2001| author=Susan Fast| page=210 | isbn=0-19-511756-5}}</ref> Folklorist Carl Lindahl, refers to these recycling of lyrics in songs as "floating lyrics". He defines it within the folk-music tradition as "lines that have circulated so long in folk communities that tradition-steeped singers call them instantly to mind and rearrange them constantly, and often unconsciously, to suit their personal and community aesthetics".<ref>Carl Lindahl, "Thrills and Miracles: Legends of Lloyd Chandler", ''[[Journal of Folklore Research]]'', Bloomington: May–December 2004, Vol. 41, Issue 2/3, pp. 133–72.</ref> In 2012, when [[Bob Dylan]] was questioned over his alleged plagiarism of others music he responded, "It's an old thing – it's part of the tradition. It goes way back."<ref>{{cite news | title=Bob Dylan Strikes Back at Critics: Addresses plagiarism charges for the first time | work=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=12 September 2012 | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/bob-dylan-strikes-back-at-critics-20120912 | accessdate=14 October 2012}}</ref> Princeton University professor of American history [[Sean Wilentz]] defended Dylan's appropriation of music stating "crediting bits and pieces of another's work is scholarly tradition, not an artistic tradition".<ref>{{cite news | title=Bob Dylan says plagiarism charges made by "wussies and pussies" | work=[[Reuters]] | date=12 September 2012 | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/09/13/entertainment-us-bobdylan-plagiarism-idUSBRE88C00720120913 | accessdate=14 October 2012}}</ref> In 1998, B.B. King stated on the issue, "I don't think anybody steals anything; all of us borrow."<ref>Newman, Richard (1998). ''African American Quotations''. Oryx Press. pp. 98. {{ISBN|1-573-56118-5}}</ref>
===Musical ideas=== Plagiarism is relevant to different [[musical style]]s in different ways.
In classical music, software exists that automatically generates music in the style of another composer, using musical analysis of their works. Most notably, [[David Cope]]<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Computer Models of Musical Creativity|first = David|last = Cope|year = 2006|publisher = Cambridge, MA: MIT Press|postscript = <!--None-->}}</ref> has written a software system called "Experiments in Musical Intelligence" (or "EMI") that is capable of analyzing and generalizing from existing music by a human composer to generate novel musical compositions in the same style. EMI's output is convincing enough to persuade human listeners that its music is human-generated to a high level of competence. For this reason, Cope's work has been said to not produce original music. A different approach is being followed by [[Melomics]], a technology focused on teaching computers the rules of music composition, not the works of previous composers. This technology has opened the way to truly creative computer-composers, like [[Iamus (computer)|Iamus]] and [[Melomics109]]. The records produced ([[Iamus (album)|Iamus' album]] and [[0music]]) are in the computer's own style, so they cannot be considered a pastiche or plagiarism of previous works.
According to [[Theodor Adorno]]'s highly controversial view, [[popular music]] in general employs extensive plagiarism: variety in the musical material occurs in details whereas genuinely original musical content tends to be sparse when compared to [[classical music|classical]] or [[art music]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icce.rug.nl/~soundscapes/DATABASES/SWA/On_popular_music_2.shtml|title=On popular music|publisher=soundscapes.info|last=Adorno|first= Theodor W.}}</ref> Contradicting this claim is classical music critic Mark Swed of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' who said that many composers used material from previous composers—for example, "[[John Williams]] all but lifted the core idea of his [[Star Wars (soundtrack)|soundtrack score]] from the Scherzo of [[Erich Korngold]]'s [[Symphony in F-sharp major (Korngold)|Symphony in F-sharp Major]], written 25 years earlier."<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/la-et-cm-blurred-lines-classical-notebook-20150314-column.html |title='Blurred Lines' verdict would rock Amadeus and other great composers|first= Mark|last= Swed|work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date= 2015-03-14|publisher=[[Tribune Co]] |location=[[Los Angeles]] |issn=0458-3035 |quote=Mark Swed |accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref>
===Sampling=== {{Main|Sampling (music)}} Sampling has long been an area of contention from a legal perspective. Early sampling artists simply used portions of other artists' recordings, without permission; once [[hip hop]] and other music incorporating samples began to make significant money, the original artists began to take legal action, claiming [[copyright]] infringement. Some sampling artists fought back, claiming their samples were [[fair use]] (a legal doctrine in the USA that is not universal). International sampling is governed by agreements such as the [[Berne Convention for the Protection of Literary and Artistic Works]] and the [[WIPO Copyright and Performances and Phonograms Treaties Implementation Act]].
Today, most major artists obtain prior authorization to use samples, a process known as "clearing," by gaining permission to use the sample and, usually, paying an upfront fee and/or a cut of the royalties to the original artist. Independent musicians, lacking the funds and legal assistance to clear samples, are at a disadvantage unless they seek the services of a professional sample replay company or producer.
Recently, the [[free culture movement]], started mainly by [[Lawrence Lessig]], has prompted many audio works to be licensed under a [[Creative Commons]] license that allows for legal sampling of the work provided the resulting work(s) are licensed under the same terms.
==Cases== Usually cases of alleged plagiarism are settled out of court, due to the expense of litigation. Most artists try and settle for costs that will be less than defending costs. Since the 1850s federal courts have published fewer than 100 opinions dealing with this issue.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://cip.law.ucla.edu/caselist.html | title=UCLA Law Copyright Infringement Project | publisher=[[UCLA School of Law]] | accessdate=23 November 2008 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081101000016/http://cip.law.ucla.edu/caselist.html | archivedate=1 November 2008 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> The Columbia Law School Library's Music Plagiarism Project provides information on many cases over the decades, with a few dating back to the 19th century.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://cip.law.ucla.edu/ |title= Music Copyright Infringement Resource |accessdate = 2012-09-05}}</ref>
===Successful suits and settlements=== *[[Solomon Linda]], was a South African musician, singer and composer best known as the composer of the song "Mbube", which later became the popular music success "The Lion Sleeps Tonight". Despite the popularity and wide use of the song, Linda died impoverished in 1962 of renal failure. In February 2006, Linda's heirs attained a legal settlement with Abilene Music company, which had the worldwide rights and had licensed the song to Disney. The primary outcomes of the settlement of February 2006 were: **The Linda heirs will receive payment for past uses of The Lion Sleeps Tonight and an entitlement to future royalties from its worldwide use. **The Lion Sleeps Tonight is acknowledged as derived from Mbube. **Solomon Linda is acknowledged as a co-composer of The Lion Sleeps Tonight and will be designated as such in the future. *In March 1963, [[the Beach Boys]] released "[[Surfin' U.S.A. (song)|Surfin' U.S.A.]]" When the single was released in 1963, the record listed [[Brian Wilson]] as the sole composer although the song was published by [[Leonard Chess|Arc Music]], [[Chuck Berry]]'s publisher. Later releases, beginning with ''[[Best of The Beach Boys]]'' in 1966, listed Chuck Berry as the songwriter. Later releases list both writers although the copyright has always been owned, since 1963, by Arc Music. Under pressure from Berry's publisher, Wilson's father and manager, [[Murry Wilson]], had given the copyright, including Brian Wilson's lyrics, to Arc Music.<ref>Pegg, Bruce. ''Brown Eyed Handsome Man'' (2002): 162–163</ref> *[[George Martin]]'s score for [[the Beatles]]' "[[All You Need Is Love]]" (1967) contained melodies from several songs thought to be [[public domain]], including "[[In the Mood]]," written by [[Joe Garland]] and [[Andy Razaf]]. While the song was in the public domain, the [[Glenn Miller]] arrangement used was not and [[EMI]] made a royalty payment to KPM Publishing in July 1967.<ref>Lewisohn, Mark. ''The Beatles: Recording Sessions'' (1988): 120</ref> * John Lennon's use of a line from [[Chuck Berry]]'s "[[You Can't Catch Me]]" ("Here come up flat top / He was movin' up with me/")<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metrolyrics.com/you-cant-catch-me-lyrics-chuck-berry.html|title=Chuck Berry - You Can't Catch Me Lyrics - MetroLyrics|work=metrolyrics.com}}</ref> the 1969 Beatles' song "[[Come Together]]" ("Here comes ol' flat-top / He come groovin' up slowly") led to a lawsuit from Berry's publisher, Big Seven Music Corp. In 1973, a settlement was reached whereby Lennon agreed to record three of Big Seven's songs on his next album. Big Seven Music Corp. again sued Lennon for breach of contract, when his 1974 album, ''[[Walls and Bridges]]'', failed to contain all three of the songs, with the court awarding the company US$6,795.<ref>{{cite web|last=Self |first=Joseph C. |year=1992 |title=Lennon vs. Levy – The 'Roots' Lawsuit |work=abbeyrd.net |url=http://www.abbeyrd.net/lenlevy.htm |accessdate=25 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703122215/http://www.abbeyrd.net/lenlevy.htm |archivedate= 3 July 2009 |df= }}</ref> *[[George Harrison]] was successfully sued in a prolonged suit that began in 1971 for plagiarizing [[The Chiffons]]' "[[He's So Fine]]" (1963) for the melody of his own "[[My Sweet Lord]]" (1970).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abbeyrd.best.vwh.net/mysweet.htm |title=The "My Sweet Lord"/"He's So Fine" Plagiarism Suit |accessdate=23 November 2008 |last=Self |first=Joseph C. |year=1993 |work=The 910 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221135306/http://abbeyrd.best.vwh.net/mysweet.htm |archivedate=21 December 2008 |df= }}</ref> In the ruling, the judge stated that he believed Harrison had not intentionally copied the song, but more than likely experienced an episode of [[cryptomnesia]].<ref>[http://abbeyrd.best.vwh.net/mysweet.htm The "My Sweet Lord"/"He's So Fine" Plagiarism Suit] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081221135306/http://abbeyrd.best.vwh.net/mysweet.htm |date=21 December 2008 }}</ref> *In 1971, [[Johnny Cash]] paid songwriter [[Gordon Jenkins]] an out-of-court settlement of US$75,000 for plagiarizing liberally from Jenkins' 1953 song "[[Crescent City Blues]]," for Cash's 1955 single "[[Folsom Prison Blues]]" (re-released in 1968).<ref>{{cite book |title=Goodbye: In Search of Gordon Jenkins |last=Jenkins |first=Bruce |year=2005 |publisher=Frog Books |isbn=978-1-58394-126-3 |page= |pages=191 |url=https://www.google.com/search?tbo=p&tbm=bks&q=shameless+ripoff+%22folsom+prison+blues%22+inauthor:Jenkins |accessdate=9 May 2012}}</ref><ref>Streissguth, Michael. ''Johnny Cash at Folsom Prison: The Making of a Masterpiece'' (Da Capo Press, 2004): 21</ref> *On [[Led Zeppelin]]'s album ''[[Led Zeppelin II]]'' (1969), parts of the song "[[Bring It On Home (Sonny Boy Williamson II song)|Bring It On Home]]" were copied from [[Sonny Boy Williamson II|Sonny Boy Williamson]]'s 1963 recording of "Bring It On Home," written by [[Willie Dixon]]. On the same album, "[[The Lemon Song]]" included an adaptation of [[Howlin' Wolf]]'s "[[Killing Floor (Howlin' Wolf song)|Killing Floor]]." In 1972, Arc Music, the publishing arm of [[Chess Records]], brought a lawsuit against Led Zeppelin for copyright infringement over "Bring It On Home" and "The Lemon Song"; the case was settled out of court for an undisclosed sum. *Led Zeppelin's song "[[Whole Lotta Love]]" contained lyrics that were derivative of Willie Dixon's 1962 song "You Need Love." In 1985, Dixon filed a copyright infringement suit, resulting in an out-of-court settlement. Later pressings of ''Led Zeppelin II'' credit Dixon as co-writer.<ref>Goldstein, Patrick. "Whole Lotta Litigation". ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 3 February 1985: N72</ref> *Led Zeppelin also paid a settlement to the publisher of [[Ritchie Valens]]' song "Ooh! My Head" over "[[Boogie with Stu]]" (from their album ''[[Physical Graffiti]]'') which borrowed from Valens' song.<ref>Lehmer, Larry. ''The Day the Music Died: The Last Tour of Buddy Holly, the Big Bopper and Ritchie Valens'' (2004): 166</ref> *[[Rod Stewart]] was successfully sued by Brazilian songwriter [[Jorge Ben Jor]], over "[[Da Ya Think I'm Sexy?]]" melody and chorus similarities to Ben's 1972 song "Taj Mahal".<ref>{{cite web|title=Brazil's alchemist of funk - Tropical superstar Jorge Ben Jor brings the funk to Germany|url=http://www.expatica.com/de/lifestyle_leisure/lifestyle/brazils-alchemist-of-funk-abrtropical-superstar-jorge-ben-jor-brings-the-funk-to-germanybr-9736.html|publisher=Expatica|accessdate=8 November 2013}}</ref> *In autumn 1984 and throughout 1985, [[Huey Lewis]] sued [[Ray Parker, Jr.]], for [[plagiarism]], alleging that Parker stole the melody of the song "[[Ghostbusters (song)|Ghostbusters]]" (the theme from the [[Ghostbusters|movie of the same name]]), from Lewis's 1983 song "[[I Want A New Drug]]." Lewis dropped the lawsuit after the two parties settled out-of-court in 1995. Lewis had been approached to compose the main theme song for the ''Ghostbusters'' movie, but had declined due to his work on the soundtrack for ''[[Back to the Future]]''. It was reported in 2001 that Lewis allegedly breached an agreement not to mention the original suit, doing so on [[VH1]]'s ''[[Behind the Music]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vh1.com/artists/news/1442127/20010323/lewis_huey.jhtml |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090613074344/http://www.vh1.com/artists/news/1442127/20010323/lewis_huey.jhtml |archivedate=13 June 2009 |df= }}</ref> *According to the book ''Sharp Dressed Men'' by former [[ZZ Top]] stage manager David Blayney, who was with the band for 15 years, sound engineer Linden Hudson co-wrote much of the material on the ZZ Top album ''[[Eliminator (album)|Eliminator]]'' album as a live-in high-tech music teacher to band members [[Frank Beard (musician)|Frank Beard]] and [[Billy Gibbons]]. Despite continued denials by the band, it settled a five-year legal battle with Hudson in 1986, paying him $600,000 after he proved he held the copyright to the song "Thug" which appeared on ''Eliminator''.<ref>Blayney, David (1994). ''Sharp Dressed Men''. New York: Hyperion. pp. 196–202. {{ISBN|0-7868-8005-8}}</ref> *Due to similarities to "[[The Air That I Breathe]]", a song recorded by [[The Hollies]] in 1973, [[Radiohead]] were successfully sued for plagiarism over their 1992 song "[[Creep (Radiohead song)|Creep]]". Consequently, songwriters [[Albert Hammond]] and [[Mike Hazlewood]] are credited as co-writers.<ref>"[http://www.alberthammond.com/song.php?id=426 Song info: 'Creep'] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011042328/http://www.alberthammond.com/song.php?id=426 |date=11 October 2012 }}", ''AlbertHammond.com''.</ref><ref>Wardle, Ben. "[https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2009/may/12/coldplay-yusuf-islam Get off Coldplay's case – similar songs can co-exist peacefully]". Guardian.co.uk. 12 May 2009. Retrieved on 21 April 2013.</ref> *[[Oasis (band)|Oasis]]'s 1994 single "[[Whatever (Oasis song)|Whatever]]" was initially credited as being written by the band's lead guitarist [[Noel Gallagher]]; a subsequent lawsuit awarded a co-writing credit to musical comedian [[Neil Innes]] due to similarities to his song "[[How Sweet to Be an Idiot]]." Oasis were also successfully sued for $500,000 by [[The New Seekers]] after the 1994 song "[[Shakermaker]]" was alleged to have taken its melody from "[[I'd Like to Teach the World to Sing]]". An Oasis song "Step Out," was originally intended for the ''[[(What's the Story) Morning Glory?]]'' album but was taken off after [[Stevie Wonder]] requested 10% of the royalties, as the chorus bore a similarity to his hit "[[Uptight (Everything's Alright)]]." Instead it was placed as a [[B-side]] on their 1996 single "[[Don't Look Back in Anger]]," and "Uptight" writers Wonder, [[Henry Cosby]] and [[Sylvia Moy]] received credit for writing the song, along with [[Noel Gallagher]]. *In 2000, a U.S. Court of Appeals ruled against [[the Rolling Stones]]' former record company [[ABKCO Records]], determining that two [[Robert Johnson]] songs recorded by the group, "[[Love in Vain]]" and "[[Stop Breaking Down]]" were not in the public domain.<ref>http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117783132/?refcatid=16 ''Variety'' "Court rules Stones stole from Johnson" 27 June 2000</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F3/217/217.F3d.684.98-56145.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100517152537/http://bulk.resource.org/courts.gov/c/F3/217/217.F3d.684.98-56145.html |archivedate=17 May 2010 |df= }} ABKCO Music, Inc. versus Stephen Lavere & Delta Haze (2000)</ref> *In 2005, [[Belgian]] songwriter [[Salvatore Acquaviva]] won a judgement against [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], claiming that her 1998 hit "[[Frozen (Madonna song)|Frozen]]" had been lifted from his early-1980s song, "Ma Vie Fout le camp." The judge declined to award [[damages]], but did order the withdrawal of all remaining discs for sale and barred the song from airplay on Belgian TV and radio.<ref>{{cite news | title=No ray of light for Madonna in song plagiarism case | work=[[Sydney Morning Herald]] | date=20 November 2005 | url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/people/no-ray-of-light/2005/11/19/1132017024510.html | accessdate=23 November 2008}}</ref> See ''[[Frozen (Madonna song)#Plagiarism case|Frozen (Madonna song): Plagiarism]].'' *In early 2006, the writers of [[Lee Hyori]]'s song "Get Ya" were accused of plagiarizing [[Britney Spears]]' 2005 song "[[Do Somethin']]." This eventually led Lee Hyori to stop promoting the song and contributed to the failure of the song and its album, [[Dark Angel (Lee Hyori album)|''Dark Angel'']].{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} *In early 2007, [[Timbaland]] was [[Timbaland plagiarism controversy|alleged to have plagiarized]] several elements (both motifs and samples) in the songs "Acidjazzed Evening" by [[Janne Suni]], and "[[Do It (Nelly Furtado song)|Do It]]" on the 2006 album ''[[Loose (Nelly Furtado album)|Loose]]'' by [[Nelly Furtado]] without giving credit or compensation.{{citation needed|date=February 2011}} *American musician [[Les Paul]] was successfully sued for plagiarizing [[Romania]]n composer Richard Stein's "[[Sanie cu zurgălăi]]" (1937) as "Johnny (Is the Boy for Me)" (1953).<ref>{{cite news |first=Anca |last=Nicoleanu |title=Zici că n-ai plagiat şi, gata, ai scăpat |date=22 February 2007 |accessdate=19 June 2009 |url=http://www.cotidianul.ro/zici_ca_n_ai_plagiat_si_gata_ai_scapat-22511.html |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090604124914/http://cotidianul.ro/zici_ca_n_ai_plagiat_si_gata_ai_scapat-22511.html |archivedate= 4 June 2009 |language= Romanian}}</ref> *A lawsuit filed by Tommy Dunbar and James Gangwer of the 1970s power pop band [[the Rubinoos]] alleged [[Avril Lavigne]] stole their song "I Wanna Be Your Boyfriend" and reworked it into her best-selling single "[[Girlfriend (Avril Lavigne song)|Girlfriend]]." The case was settled for an undisclosed sum in January 2008.<ref>{{cite news | title=Canadian rocker stung by claims of plagiarism | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=7 July 2007 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2007/jul/07/pop.music| accessdate=23 November 2008 | last=Luscombe | first=Richard | location=London}}</ref> *[[The Black Eyed Peas]] were successfully sued by Ohio disc jockey Lynn Tolliver, claiming that his song "[[I Need a Freak]]" was sampled without his permission in the Black Eyed Peas song "[[My Humps]]." Lynn Tolliver won $1.2 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2011/06/former_cleveland_dj_lynn_tolli.html|title=Former Cleveland DJ Lynn Tolliver wins $1.2 million in music sample suit|work=cleveland.com}}</ref> *In 2009, Norman Lurie, then the head of [[Larrikin Records|Larrikin Music]], successfully sued the members of the disbanded Australian group [[Men at Work]] on the basis that "a pattern of notes in five bars of a 93-bar song"<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/the-biggest-hit-20120716-224x7.html | work=The Sydney Morning Herald | title=The biggest hit}}</ref> in their hit "[[Down Under (song)|Down Under]]" sounded too much like the song "[[Kookaburra (song)|Kookaburra sits in the old gum tree]]," to which Larrikin owned the rights. *Led Zeppelin's song "[[Dazed and Confused (song)|Dazed and Confused]]" was derived from a 1967 [[Jake Holmes]] song of the same name, which had been performed by [[Jimmy Page]] when he was with [[The Yardbirds]].<ref name=Fast>Fast, Susan. "Dazed and Confused". ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=lZslRYfLlKEC&pg=PA21&dq=&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBoQ6AEwAWoVChMI1o759dalxwIVCg8aCh1Y8wAr#v=onepage&q&f=false In the Houses of the Holy: Led Zeppelin and the Power of Rock Music]'', p. 21. Oxford, 2001. {{ISBN|0-19-511756-5}}</ref><ref>Matt Resnicoff, Matt. "In Through the Out Door: Jimmy Page Goes Back to Led Zeppelin" ''Musician'' November 1990: 62</ref> In June 2010, Holmes filed a lawsuit against the guitarist for copyright infringement in a [[United States District Court]], claiming Page knowingly copied his work.<ref>[http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/music/led_zeppelin_sued_by_folk_singer_Onb6nSTXepES8W0KURCX0O Led Zeppelin sued by folk singer for alleged plagiarism]. ''[[New York Post]]''. Retrieved 6 July 2010.</ref> The case was dismissed with prejudice in January 2012 following a stipulation filed by both parties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/california/cacdce/2:2010cv04789/476306/27|title=ORDER DISMISSING ACTION WITH PREJUDICE by Judge Dolly M for Jake Holmes v. James Patrick Page et al :: Justia Dockets & Filings|work=Justia Dockets & Filings}}</ref> The 2012 Led Zeppelin release ''[[Celebration Day (film)|Celebration Day]]'' credits the song to "Jimmy Page, inspired by Jake Holmes". *[[Will.i.am]] and [[Chris Brown (American entertainer)|Chris Brown]] were accused of stealing house producers [[Mat Zo]] and [[Arty (musician)|Arty]] track "Rebound", upon the release of their 2013 collaborative single "Let's Go". This claim was backed by [[Anjunabeats]], the record label behind the producers, in a formal public statement.<ref>{{cite web|author=|date=17 April 2013|url=http://www.trancefixxed.co.uk/news/will-i-am-rebound-rip-off/|title=Will.i.am Rips Off Arty & Mat Zo's 'Rebound' for Latest Single |publisher=TranceFixxed|accessdate=18 September 2014}}</ref> Will.i.am admitted that he did take the track, following an outcry on social media, and that he was rectifying the issue in an undisclosed licensing deal with the producers.<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff Reporter|date=23 April 2013|title=Will.i.am Admits To Stealing Song: Did Chris Brown Throw The 'Scream And Shout' Artists Under The Bus?|url=http://www.idesigntimes.com/articles/4839/20130423/will-i-am-steal-song-chris-brown-copyright-infringement-mat-zo-arty-lets-go.htm|publisher=iDesignTimes|accessdate=18 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530074310/http://www.idesigntimes.com/articles/4839/20130423/will-i-am-steal-song-chris-brown-copyright-infringement-mat-zo-arty-lets-go.htm|archive-date=30 May 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> *[[Shakira]]'s Spanish-language single "[[Loca (Shakira song)|Loca]]" was ruled a copy from another songwriter's work. On 19 August 2014, [[Alvin Hellerstein]], senior judge of the [[U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York]], concluded that the Spanish version of "Loca" had been plagiarised from "Loca con su Tiguere", a mid-1990s song composed by Dominican songwriter Ramon "Arias" Vasquez. Hellerstein ruled in favour of Vasquez and found the two songs to be similar in structure and rhythm. As the Spanish version of "Loca" features Bello singing numerous portions, the judge reasoned that it too was plagiarised from Vasquez's song.<ref>{{cite web|author=Fox News Latino|date=20 August 2014|title=Judge: Shakira's Hit Song 'Loca' Ripped Off From Dominican Songerwriter's Work|url=http://latino.foxnews.com/latino/entertainment/2014/08/20/judge-shakira-hit-song-loca-ripped-off-from-dominican-songerwriter-work/|publisher=FOX News Network|accessdate=18 September 2014}}</ref> After a trial phase, [[Sony ATV|SonyATV Latin]] and Sony/ATV Discos (the distributors of the Spanish version of "Loca" in the United States) will pay damages to Mayimba Music, the owner of the rights to Vasquez's song and the plaintiff in the lawsuit.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gardner|first1=Eriq|date=20 August 2014|title=Shakira's Illegally Copied Song Puts Sony on Hook for Damages|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/shakiras-illegally-copied-song-puts-726532|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|accessdate=18 September 2014}}</ref> *[[Robin Thicke]] and [[Pharrell Williams]] were successfully sued for plagiarising [[Marvin Gaye]]'s song "[[Got to Give It Up]]" for his single "[[Blurred Lines]]", and "[[After the Dance (song)|After the Dance]]" for "[[Love After War (song)|Love After War]]", following a unanimous jury verdict on 10 March 2015.<ref>{{cite news | title='Blurred Lines' jury orders Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams to pay $7.4 million | url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/03/10/entertainment/feat-thr-marvin-gaye-robin-thicke-pharrell-lose-blurred-lines-lawsuit/ | accessdate=10 March 2015 | last=Gardner | first=Eriq | work=The Hollywood Reporter | date=10 March 2015}}</ref> Marvin Gaye's children, Frankie Gaye and Nona Gaye, launched legal proceedings against EMI Records and Thicke in October 2013.<ref>{{cite web | title=Marvin Gaye's Family Sues EMI Over Robin Thicke's 'Blurred Lines' | work=Billboard | date=30 October 2013 | url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5770731/marvin-gayes-family-sues-emi-over-robin-thickes-blurred-lines | accessdate=1 November 2013 | last=Gardner | first=Eriq}}</ref> In a separate allegation, Bridgeport Music claims "Blurred Lines" was remarkably similar to [[Funkadelic]]'s "[[Sexy Ways]]". Both Thicke and Pharrell attempted to thwart the Gaye and Bridgeport lawsuits by claiming their copyright claims were invalid.<ref>{{cite news | title=Robin Thicke Sues to Protect 'Blurred Lines' from Marvin Gaye's Family | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/robin-thicke-sues-protect-blurred-607492 | accessdate=1 November 2013 | last=Gardner | first=Eriq | work=The Hollywood Reporter | date=15 August 2013}}</ref> Thicke and Pharrell were ordered to pay US$7.4 million in damages to the Gaye estate.<ref>{{cite news | title=Jurors hit Robin Thicke and Pharrell Williams with $7.4-million verdict | url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-blurred-lines-copyright-trial-verdict-20150310-story.html | accessdate=10 March 2015 | last=Kim | first=Victoria | work=Los Angeles Times | date=10 March 2015}}</ref> *In April 2015, British producer [[Mark Ronson]] was forced to add additional credits to "[[Uptown Funk]]" (featuring Bruno Mars) after an out-of-court settlement had been reached with [[The Gap Band]]'s publishing company, Minder Music. [[Charlie Wilson (singer)|Charlie Wilson]], Robert Wilson, Ronnie Wilson, Rudolph Taylor and producer [[Lonnie Simmons]] were added as co-writers, and that they would receive a 17% songwriting credit each.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/6553861/uptown-funk-royalties-who-gets-paid|title=Inside the New Royalty Split for 'Uptown Funk': Who Gets Paid What|last=Christman|first=Ed|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=1 May 2015|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> Minder Music filed a claim into YouTube's content management system, which prevented publishers to receive their payment, after the song was released failing to credit the original songwriters.<ref>{{cite web|last=Breihan|first=Tom|title=The Gap Band Awarded Writing Credit On "Uptown Funk!"|url=http://www.stereogum.com/1798435/the-gap-band-awarded-a-writing-credit-on-uptown-funk/news/|work=[[Stereogum]]|publisher=[[SpinMedia]]|accessdate=30 April 2015|date=30 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6553522/uptown-funk-gains-more-writers-after-gap-bands-legal-claim|title='Uptown Funk!' Gains More Writers After Gap Band's Legal Claim|author=Ed Christman|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=1 May 2015|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref>
===Unsuccessful suits===
*During the mid-1930s, [[Ira Arnstein]] became convinced that major pop songwriters had been illegally copying his work. During 1936–46 he brought forth five plagiarism lawsuits though none proved successful.<ref>{{cite web|last=Rosen|first=Gary|title=Plagiarized or original: A playlist for the contested music of Ira B. Arnstein|url=http://blog.oup.com/2013/01/ira-arnstein-spotify/|work=OUPblog|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=22 January 2013|date=22 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicreports.com/smart_licensing/content_article.php?article_id=76&title=The+Strange+Case(s)+of+Ira+Arnstein,+Serial+Litigator|title=Smart Licensing Publication -|work=musicreports.com}}{{dead link|date=August 2018}}</ref><ref>https://www.thenation.com/article/professional-victim-ira-b-arnstein/</ref> *In 1994 [[John Fogerty]] was sued for self-plagiarism after leaving [[Fantasy Records]] and pursuing a solo career with [[Warner Bros. Records]]. Fantasy still owned the rights to the [[Creedence Clearwater Revival]] (Fogerty's former band) library. [[Saul Zaentz]], the owner of Fantasy, claimed Fogerty's song "[[The Old Man Down the Road]]" was a musical copy of the Creedence song "[[Run Through the Jungle]]." A jury found that "Old Man" was not derivative.<ref name="fantfog">{{ cite web | title=Fantasy v. Fogerty | accessdate=2010-02-03 | url=http://cip.law.ucla.edu/cases/case_fantfogerty.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100515190213/http://cip.law.ucla.edu/cases/case_fantfogerty.html | archivedate= 15 May 2010 }}</ref> See ''[[Fogerty v. Fantasy]]''. *In 1993 [[Killing Joke]] sued [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]] alleging that the riff for the latter's song "[[Come As You Are (Nirvana song)|Come as You Are]]" was copied from the riff for their song "[[Eighties (song)|Eighties]]." The lawsuit was dropped after the sudden death of Nirvana frontman [[Kurt Cobain]].<ref name="bbc">{{cite web | year = 2003 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/manchester/music/2003/07/24/killing_interview.shtml | title = Interview with Killing Joke's Geordie | accessdate = 2008-01-07 | publisher = BBC Manchester }}</ref>
*The song "Thunderbird" was originally written and performed by the Nightcaps, a band formed in the 1950s when the members were teenagers. The Nightcaps performed the song and distributed it on their album ''Wine, Wine, Wine'' but never applied for copyright. [[ZZ Top]] began performing its version of the song in 1975, and has conceded that its version is lyrically and musically identical to the Nightcaps' song. The Nightcaps sued ZZ Top for, among other things, copyright infringement, but their claims were dismissed (in 1995) because, in part, ZZ Top had registered a copyright on the song in 1975.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/1995-02-02/music/case-dismissed/|title=Case dismissed|author=Robert Wilonsky|date=22 October 2006|work=dallasobserver.com}}</ref> *In 2003 Michael Cottrill and Lawrence E. Wnukowski claimed that [[Britney Spears]]’ "[[Can’t Make You Love Me]]," from her 2000 album ''[[Oops!... I Did It Again (album)|Oops!... I Did It Again]]'', misappropriated substantial melodic material from their song "What You See is What You Get". The court was skeptical on the question of defendant's access to the plaintiff's work.<ref>{{cite web|title=Cottrill v. Spears, No. 02 – 3646, 2003 U.S. Dist. LEXIS 8823 |date=(E.D. Pa. 22 May 2003) |url=http://cip.law.ucla.edu/cases/case_cottrillspears.html |accessdate=23 November 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214062517/http://cip.law.ucla.edu/cases/case_cottrillspears.html |archivedate=14 February 2008 |df= }}</ref> *Ronald H. Selle sued the [[Bee Gees]], alleging their 1977 hit "[[How Deep Is Your Love (Bee Gees song)|How Deep Is Your Love]]" stole the melody of his own never-released 1975 song, "Let It End." The Bee Gees prevailed at trial on motion of [[judgment notwithstanding the verdict]]. Selle appealed, but the [[Seventh Circuit Court of Appeals]] upheld the verdict.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://law.justia.com/cases/federal/appellate-courts/F2/741/896/90728/|title=Ronald H. Selle, Plaintiff-appellant, v. Barry Gibb, et al., Defendants-appellants,andronald H. Selle, Plaintiff-appellee, v. Barry Gibb, et al., Defendants-appellants, 741 F.2d 896 (7th Cir. 1984)|work=Justia Law}}</ref> *On 4 December 2008 guitarist Joe Satriani filed a [[copyright infringement]] suit in Los Angeles [[United States district court|federal court]] against [[Coldplay]], claiming the [[Coldplay]] song "[[Viva la Vida]]" includes "substantial original portions" of the Satriani song "If I Could Fly" from his 2004 album, ''[[Is There Love in Space?]]''. Coldplay has denied the allegation,<ref name="coldplay.com">http://www.coldplay.com/newsdetail.php?id=242, retrieved 10 December 2008.</ref><ref name="coldplay.com"/> which has resulted in further legal action from Satriani.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7766683.stm | work=BBC News | title=Guitarist Satriani sues Coldplay | date=5 December 2008 | accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref><ref>[http://www.peoplestar.co.uk/index.html?news=287 Coldplay Sued By Joe Satriani For Allegedly Plagiarizing 'Viva La Vida' Melody »] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120726025039/http://www.peoplestar.co.uk/index.html?news=287 |date=26 July 2012 }}, ''peoplestar.co.uk'', Retrieved on 2008-12-06.</ref> On 14 September 2009, the case was dismissed by the [[United States District Court for the Central District of California|California Central District Court]], with both parties potentially agreeing to an out-of-court settlement.<ref name="NME">{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/coldplay/47325|title=Coldplay's Joe Satriani lawsuit dismissed from court|publisher=[[NME]]|date=15 September 2009}}</ref> *Baltimore songwriter [[Ray Repp]] sued composer [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]], alleging the theme song from the musical ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' was taken from his song "Till You." In 1998, a jury found Webber not liable for plagiarism.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/235906.stm | work=BBC News | title=Lloyd Webber wins Phantom battle | date=16 December 1998}}</ref> *[[Elton John]], [[Bernie Taupin]], and Big Pig Music, have been accused of plagiarism by South African photographer and songwriter Guy Hobbs. Hobbs wrote a song in 1982 entitled "Natasha," about a Russian waitress on a cruise ship, who was never allowed to leave it. The song was copyrighted in 1983, and sent to Big Pig Music (John's publisher) for a possible publishing deal, but Guy never heard back from the publisher. In 2001, Guy came across the lyric book to "[[Nikita (song)|Nikita]]" and noticed similarities with his song. Despite repeated attempts by Guy to contact John over the issue, he never heard from him, and commenced legal action in 2012.<ref>{{cite web | title=Guy Hobbs (Plaintiff) versus Sir Elton Hercules John, Bernard John Taupin, & Big Pig Music (Defendants) | work=Entertainment Law Digest | date=26 April 2012 | url=http://www.entlawdigest.com/2012/04/30/eltonJohn.pdf | accessdate=2 May 2012 | last=Voelker | first=Daniel}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Elton John is sued by songwriter for allegedly stealing lyrics to Nikita | first=Kimberley | last=Dadds | work=[[Daily Mail]] | date=27 April 2012 | page=D01 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2136170/Elton-John-sued-songwriter-allegedly-stealing-lyrics-Nikita.html | accessdate=2 May 2012 | location=London}}</ref> On 31 October 2012, a federal judge granted John and Taupin's motion to dismiss, finding that the song did not infringe Hobbs's copyright because the only similar elements were generic images and themes that are not protected under copyright law.<ref>{{cite news | title=Elton John Kicks Copyright Suit Over 'Nikita' Lyrics | first=Matthew| last=Heller | work=[[Law360]] | date=31 October 2012 | url=http://www.law360.com/ip/articles/391033/elton-john-kicks-copyright-suit-over-nikita-lyrics | accessdate=1 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Elton John's 'Nikita' Didn’t Infringe Copyright in Earlier Cold War Love Song | first=Shawn| last=Sullivan | work=[[SullivanLawNet]] | date=3 November 2012 | url=http://sullivanlaw.net/elton-johns-nikita-did-not-infringe-copyright-in-earlier-song | accessdate=5 November 2012}}</ref> *Braham v Sony Music Publishing.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lexislegalnews.com/articles/3932/shake-it-off-copyright-case-dismissed-by-california-federal-judge|title=‘Shake It Off’ Copyright Case Dismissed By California Federal Judge - Lexis Legal News|website=www.lexislegalnews.com|access-date=2016-12-02}}</ref> R&B singer Jesse Braham sued Taylor Swift for $42 million. He alleged that Swift had plagiarized his song 'Haters gone hate' in her 2014 hit "Shake It Off". Court dismissed the action, holding that the plaintiff had failed to establish a sufficient claim.
=== Unsettled, alleged, and forgiven incidents === The following are accusations of plagiarism appearing in [[Notability|notable]] media:
*Ritchie Valens' 1959 song "Ooh! My Head" is a thinly veiled cover of [[Little Richard]]'s 1958 single "Ooh! My Soul."<ref>{{cite book |title=Mexican American Mojo: Popular Music, Dance, and Urban Culture in Los Angeles, 1935–1968 |last=Macías |first=Anthony |year=2008 |publisher=Duke University Press |isbn=978-0-822-34322-6 |page= |pages=188 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9Sf8V7FUjZAC&pg=PA188&dq=Mac%C3%8Cas+Little+Richard+Ooh!+My+Soul&hl=en&sa=X&ei=QxAcVPDLHcb88QWlt4DABg&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Mac%C3%8Cas%20Little%20Richard%20Ooh!%20My%20Soul&f=false |accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref> Richard was never credited in the Valens song. *The opening of the Beatles' 1963 song "[[All My Loving]]" sounds almost identical to the first two bars of the solo in [[the Dave Brubeck Quartet]]'s song "[[Kathy's Waltz]]", which was released in 1959.<ref>{{cite web|last=Farrell|first=Paul|date=5 December 2012|title=Jazz Great Dave Brubeck Dead: Top 10 Facts You Need to Know|url=http://www.heavy.com/news/2012/12/dave-brubeck-dead-jazz-great-take-5/|work=Heavy News|publisher=Heavy.com|accessdate=8 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Levenson|first=Jeff|date=16 April 1994|title=Jazz Blue Notes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QggEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA45&dq|journal=Billboard|volume=106|issue=16|pages=45|accessdate=8 November 2013}}</ref> *[[Peter Meaden]], manager of the High Numbers (before the band changed their name to [[the Who]]), has been accused of plagiarising a 1963 recording of "Misery" by [[the Dynamics]], for their debut single B-side "[[Zoot Suit (song)|Zoot Suit]]".<ref>{{cite web|author=Dr. J.|year=2011|title=Misery - The Who Plagiarized Michigan Artists|url=http://www.michiganrockandrolllegends.com/dr-js-blog/122-misery-the-who-plagiarized-michigan-artists|publisher=Michigan Rock and Roll Legends|accessdate=8 November 2013}}</ref> The A-side "[[I'm the Face]]" guitar and harmonica riffs are also very similar to [[Slim Harpo]]'s "I've Got Love If You Want It". Both songs are credited only to Peter Meaden on the single. *[[Deep Purple]]'s 1970 song "[[Child in Time]]" is based on [[It's a Beautiful Day]]'s "[[It's a Beautiful Day (album)|Bombay Calling]]", who were never credited.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AVQbF9lTBwgC&lpg=PA206&dq=%22Bombay%20Calling%22%20%22Child%20in%20Time%22&ie=ISO-8859-1&pg=PR4#v=onepage&q=%22Bombay%20Calling%22%20%22Child%20in%20Time%22&f=false|chapter=Deep Purple in Rock|title=The Mojo Collection|publisher=Mojo|page=206|isbn=978-1-84195-973-3|accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref> Ian Gillan during an interview with author Martin Popoff, admitted the song was "nicked".<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=86QALKyWGHQC&q=%22Bombay+Calling%22+%22Child+in+Time%22&dq=%22Bombay+Calling%22+%22Child+in+Time%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jb6LVcGpH8_f8AW0mq-gBQ&redir_esc=y|chapter=Child in Time|title=The Top 500 Heavy Metal Songs of All Time|publisher=ECW Press|page=50|isbn=978-1-55022-530-3|accessdate=24 June 2015}}</ref> *Deep Purple's 1970 song "[[Black Night]]" is a liberal uncredited take of [[Ricky Nelson]]'s 1962 single "[[Summertime (George Gershwin song)|Summertime]]", itself a reworking of the [[George Gershwin]] standard, using the same two-bar pentatonic riff.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7ctjc6UWCm4C&pg=PT285&lpg=PT285&dq=&source=bl&ots=YEloBm1FF2&sig=i-6XjVbFYyGERXx4iFks4cxx4oQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBQQ6AEwADgKahUKEwjCxsiT36XHAhXBXBoKHf00AFs#v=onepage&q=&f=false|chapter=Deep Purple|title=The Rough Guide to Rock|publisher=Rough Guides|page=278|isbn=1-85828-457-0|accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://home.swipnet.se/rogerglover/text/albums.htm |year=1993 |work=Rumba Magazine |title=The Making of Black Night |accessdate=12 August 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604170210/http://home.swipnet.se/rogerglover/text/albums.htm |archive-date=4 June 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Jon Lord during an interview on ''Heavy Metal Britannia'', admitted the song was "nicked".<ref>BBC-Heavy Metal Brittania: at the 42:30 timeframe of the programme</ref> *The riff in Deep Purple's 1972 song "[[Smoke on the Water]]" bears a resemblance to [[Astrud Gilberto]]'s 1965 song "[[Look to the Rainbow (Astrud Gilberto album)|Maria Quiet]]", arranged by [[Gil Evans]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://rockonmagazine.es/deep-purple-parecidos-razonables/ |year=2015 |work=Rock On Magazine |title=DEEP PURPLE... ¿PARECIDOS RAZONABLES? - ROCK ON |accessdate=17 December 2016| language=Spanish}}</ref> *Musicologists have put forward the claim [[Pink Floyd]]'s album ''[[The Dark Side of the Moon]]'' contains uncredited elements taken from American electronic music duo [[Beaver & Krause]]'s 1971 album ''Gandharva''. In particular the opening sound effects to "Soft/White", the vocal performance in the song "[[The Great Gig in the Sky]]" sounds identical to "Walkin'", and the saxophone phrasing of "[[Us and Them (song)|Us and Them]]" is similar to "By Your Grace" and "Good Places".<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cAiL9oTFz78C&lpg=PA73&dq=Gandharva%20Beaver%20Krause&pg=PA73#v=onepage&q=influence%20Gandharva%20Beaver%20Krause&f=false|chapter=Worked Out Within the Grooves|title=Speak to Me: The Legacy of Pink Floyd's The Dark Side of the Moon|publisher=MPG Books|page=74|isbn=0-7546-4018-3|accessdate=25 June 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|authors=Peter Henderson, Phil Sutcliffe, and John Bungey|title=Pink Floyd's Dark Side of the Moon 4|work=Mojo|date=March 1998}}</ref> *[[Eric Clapton]] claimed sole credit for "Give Me Strength", a song released in 1974, but was originally written in 1939 by Chicago gospel singer-songwriter Louise King Mathews.<ref>{{cite news|last=Royko|first=Mike|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=CXFkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rn0NAAAAIBAJ&pg=4876,260470&dq=en|title=Uncredited author of Clapton hit not outraged|work=The Calgary Herald|date=11 June 1976|page=45|accessdate=2015-04-16}}</ref> Mathews was financially disadvantaged and could not afford to take the copyright matter to court when she heard the Clapton version during the 1970s. *Australian rock band [[The Angels (Australian band)|The Angels]] have been accused of plagiarising [[Status Quo (band)|Status Quo]]'s 1974 song "Lonely Night" for their 1976 anthem "[[Am I Ever Gonna See Your Face Again]]". When producers [[Vanda & Young]] first heard the song in the studio, they urged the band to re-record it at a different speed and adding sound effects to avoid a potential lawsuit.<ref>{{cite news | title=Australian anthems: the Angels – Am I Ever Gonna See Your Face Again | work=[[The Guardian]] | date=15 April 2014 | url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/australia-culture-blog/2014/apr/15/australian-anthems-the-angels-am-i-ever-gonna-see-your-face-again| accessdate=14 May 2015 | last=Mason | first=Darryl | location=London}}</ref> *Music producer [[Quincy Jones]] claims [[Michael Jackson]] plagiarized the synthesizer bass riff for "[[Billie Jean]]" from the earlier 1982 [[Donna Summer]] arrangement of "[[State of Independence]]".<ref>{{cite news|agency=Agence France-Presse|url=http://entertainment.inquirer.net/261114/entertainment-michael-jackson-quincy-jones-plagiarism-king-of-pop-thriller-state-of-independence-donna-summer-greg-phillinganes-dont-stop-til-you-get-enough|title=Michael Jackson stole songs, says music producer Quincy Jones|accessdate=17 February 2018|date=8 February 2018|work=[[The Inquirer]] | location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Donna Summer's 'State of Independence' Streams Increase After Quincy Jones Alleges Michael Jackson 'Stole' Song|work=Billboard|date=10 February 2018|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8099085/donna-summer-state-of-independence-streams-michael-jackson-billie-jean-quincy-jones|accessdate=17 February 2018|last=Caulfield|first=Keith}}</ref> *[[Rod Stewart]]'s 1988 single "[[Forever Young (Rod Stewart song)|Forever Young]]", not only has the same title as the 1973 Bob Dylan [[Forever Young (Bob Dylan song)|song of the same name]], but similar musical ideas and lyrics. When this was pointed out to the singer, a deal was struck via Bob Dylan's attorney where royalties were split 50-50, in which Stewart donated his share to charity.<ref name=song_same>{{cite web|last=Goldstein|first=Patrick|title=Rod Stewart Sounds an Echo of Dylan|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-06-26/entertainment/ca-8083_1_rod-stewart|work=Los Angeles Times|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=26 June 1988|accessdate=27 July 2015}}</ref> *The [[Anu Malik]] song "Tu Waaqif Nahin" used in the 1996 Bollywood film ''[[Khiladiyon Ka Khiladi]]'' bears remarkable similarities to the 1975 [[ABBA]] song "[[Fernando]]".{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} *In 1997, [[The Rolling Stones]] voluntarily credited [[k.d. lang]] and her writing partner [[Ben Mink]] on their song "[[Anybody Seen My Baby?]]", after a representative of the group noticed a resemblance to lang's 1992 hit single, "[[Constant Craving]]."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://articles.latimes.com/1997/sep/02/entertainment/ca-28036 | work=Los Angeles Times | first=Shauna | last=Snow | title=Arts and entertainment reports from The Times, national and international news services and the nation's press | date=2 September 1997}}</ref> *Coldplay were briefly accused of copying portions of "[[Viva la Vida]]" from "The Songs I Didn't Write" by American alternative band Creaky Boards.<ref>{{cite news|first=Guy|last=Adams|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/the-song-they-didnt-write-coldplay-are-accused-of-plagiarism-by-american-band-849992.html|title=The song they didn't write? Coldplay are accused of plagiarism by American band|accessdate=2008-11-11|date=19 June 2008|work=[[The Independent]] | location=London}}</ref> Creaky Boards later retracted the accusations and speculated that both songs may have been inspired by the video game ''[[The Legend of Zelda (video game)|The Legend of Zelda]]''.<ref name="Telegraph">{{cite news|first=Nicole|last=Martin|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/celebritynews/2163625/Coldplay-didn%27t-copy-us,-says-American-band.html|title=Coldplay didn't copy us, says American band|accessdate=2008-11-11|date=20 June 2008|work=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] | location=London}}</ref> *A portion of the [[Bruce Springsteen]] single "[[Radio Nowhere]]" sounds similar to [[Tommy Tutone]]'s 1982 hit, "[[867-5309/Jenny]]." [[Tommy Heath]]'s response was "I'm really honored at a similarity, if any, I think there's too much suing in the world now."<ref>{{cite web|title=Sue Me, Sue You: Musical 'Plagiarism' in court |first=Carl F. |last=Horowitz |url=http://www.nlpc.org/view.asp?action=viewArticle&aid=2229 |accessdate=23 November 2008 |publisher=[[National Legal and Policy Center]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080524041323/http://www.nlpc.org/view.asp?action=viewArticle&aid=2229 |archivedate=24 May 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *The ''[[New York Post]]'' reported similarities between the [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]]' "Dani California" and [[Tom Petty]]'s "Mary Jane's Last Dance" could turn into a lawsuit. Petty responded in a ''Rolling Stone'' interview: <blockquote> The truth is, I seriously doubt that there is any negative intent there. And a lot of rock & roll songs sound alike. Ask [[Chuck Berry]]. [[The Strokes]] took "[[American Girl (Tom Petty song)|American Girl]]" [for their song "[[Last Nite]]"], and I saw an interview with them where they actually admitted it. That made me laugh out loud. I was like, "OK, good for you." It doesn’t bother me.<ref>{{cite web | title=Tom Petty Doubts Chili Peppers Similarity Had "Negative Intent" | work=[[Rolling Stone]] | date=28 June 2006 | url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/tom-petty-doubts-chili-peppers-similarity-had-negative-intent-20060628 | accessdate=5 September 2012 | last=Greene | first=Andy}}</ref> </blockquote>
*Søren Rasted (formerly of [[Aqua (band)|Aqua]]) has been accused of copying [[Kate Bush]]'s "[[Running Up that Hill]]" for a song composed for the winner of the [[X Factor (Denmark)|''X Factor'' Denmark]] contest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ekstrabladet.tv/nationentv/article1147458.ece |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090401072657/http://ekstrabladet.tv/nationentv/article1147458.ece |archivedate= 1 April 2009 |df= }}</ref> *Korean pop artist [[G-Dragon]] has been accused of plagiarism by Sony Music, as his tracks "Heartbreaker" and "Butterfly" are similar to [[Flo Rida]]'s "Right Round" and [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]]'s "She's Electric", respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/special/2009/09/178_52518.html|title=YG Hits Sony Over Plagiarism Allegations|date=25 September 2009|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/opinon/2009/10/137_54413.html|title=Is Plagiarism a New Genre?|date=28 October 2009|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref> *[[iTunes]] has found cases of musical plagiarism using software that automatically identifies a CD's track information when it's loaded, most notably the many instances with pianist [[Joyce Hatto]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Too Perfect Harmony | first=Mike | last=Musgrove | work=[[Washington Post]] | date=22 February 2007 | page=D01 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/02/21/AR2007022102037.html | accessdate=23 November 2008}}</ref> *[[The Black Eyed Peas]] were charged in January 2010 by Ebony Latrice Batts (known on stage as Phoenix Phenom), claiming that "[[Boom Boom Pow]]" is just a copy of her song "Boom Dynamite," which she sent to [[Interscope Records]], the Black Eyed Peas' record label. The suit is ongoing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.inentertainment.co.uk/20100128/black-eyed-peas-sued-for-plagiarism-boom-boom-pow-copied-boom-dynamite/ |title=In Entertainment - Page not found |publisher= |accessdate=6 October 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111004020429/http://www.inentertainment.co.uk/20100128/black-eyed-peas-sued-for-plagiarism-boom-boom-pow-copied-boom-dynamite/ |archivedate= 4 October 2011 |df= }}</ref> *Stefani Joanne Angelina Germanotta, better known by her stage name [[Lady Gaga]], garnered much controversy in 2011 for her single [[Born This Way (song)|Born this Way]], which critics accused of sharing strong similarities with [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna's]] 1989 hit single "[[Express Yourself (Madonna song)|Express Yourself]]". When interviewed by [[ABC News]] in 2012, Madonna was asked about the similarities between "Born This Way" and "Express Yourself", stating: "When I heard [[Born This Way (song)|Born this Way]] on the radio ... I said, 'that sounds very familiar' ... It felt reductive." She also came to report to [[The Newsweek Daily Beast Company]] what she had in mind when she heard "Born This Way": "I thought, 'What a wonderful way to redo my song'. I mean, I recognised the chord changes. I thought it was… interesting."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.co.uk/madonna/news/madonna-lady-gagas-born-this-way-sounded-familiar|title=Madonna: Lady GaGa's Born This Way "Sounded Familiar" - MTV UK|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref> *Australian singer [[Delta Goodrem]] has been accused of copying the music of [[Arcade Fire]]'s 2005 song "[[Rebellion (Lies)]]" for her own 2012 single "[[Sitting on Top of the World (Delta Goodrem song)|Sitting on Top of the World]]".<ref>{{cite news | title=Delta accused of ripping off Arcade Fire | last=Staff | work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]] | date=29 April 2012 | page=D01 |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/delta-goodrems-sitting-on-top-of-the-world-allegedly-musically-similar-to-arcade-fires-2005-song-rebellion-lies/story-e6frewyr-1226342295915 | accessdate=2 May 2012}}</ref> *The [[Beastie Boys]] were sued in May 2012 by Hip Hop label Tuf America, over misappropriation and infringing copyright for "[[Hold It, Now Hit It]]" and "[[The New Style (song)|The New Style]]" from ''[[Licensed to Ill]]'', allegedly using portions of [[Trouble Funk]]'s 1982 song "Drop the Bomb." In addition, the Beastie Boys were also sued for using the "Drop the Bomb" drum sound in ''[[Paul's Boutique]]'' track "[[Car Thief]]" and sampling Trouble Funk's 1982 song "Say What?" for another ''Paul's Boutique'' track entitled "[[Shadrach (Beastie Boys song)|Shadrach]]", without permission.<ref>{{cite news | title=Beastie Boys sued over sampling | first=Eriq | last=Gardner | work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | date=8 May 2012 | page=D01 |url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/industry/legal-and-management/adam-yauch-sued-over-beastie-boys-sampling-1006999562.story | accessdate=9 May 2012}}</ref> *[[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] has been accused of plagiarism by record label Vallejo Music Group (VMG).<ref>{{cite web | title=VMG Salsoul (Plaintiff) versus Madonna Louise Ciccone, Shep Pettibone, & Webo Girl Publishing (Defendants) | work=UCLA Law | date=11 July 2012 | url=http://cip.law.ucla.edu/inplay/Documents/Salsoul%20Complaint.pdf | accessdate=16 November 2012 | last=Besser | first=Robert}}</ref> VMG claims Madonna stole samples from the 1977 single "Ooh I Love It (Love Break)" by [[Salsoul Orchestra]], for her 1990 charting song "[[Vogue (Madonna song)|Vogue]]". In the lawsuit, VMG allege that horns and strings were taken from the earlier track and used in "Vogue" without permission, and intentionally hidden within the mix.<ref>{{cite news | title=Madonna is 'sued after not paying for samples' in her hit Vogue… | first=Staff | last=Reporter | work=[[Daily Mail]] | date=13 July 2012 | page=D01 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-2172917/Madonna-sued-paying-samples-hit-Vogue-22-years-songs-release.html | accessdate=16 November 2012 | location=London}}</ref> The lawsuit was filed in July 2012 with the company seeking damages in addition to royalties gained from "Vogue".<ref>{{cite news | title=Madonna's copyright row over hit Vogue | first=James | last=Mills | work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]] | date=14 July 2012 | page=D01 |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/4428804/Madonnas-copyright-row-over-hit-Vogue.html | accessdate=16 November 2012 | location=London}}</ref> *[[Def Leppard]] is considering legal action against [[One Direction]], over claims the boy band's single "[[Midnight Memories]]" sounds similar to "[[Pour Some Sugar on Me]]."<ref>{{cite news|author=Kate Hind|date=8 December 2013|title=One Direction song 'contains similarities to Def Leppard tune from Eighties'|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/lifestyle/going-out/music/one-direction-song-contains-similarities-2904186|work=The Mirror|accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Dana|date=17 December 2013|title=Did One Direction Plagiarize Def Leppard's "Pour Some Sugar On Me?"|url=http://eddietrunk.com/did-one-direction-plagiarize-def-leppards-pour-some-sugar-on-me/|publisher=Eddie Trunk|accessdate=17 December 2013}}</ref> In September 2014, some observers noticed similarities between One Direction's song "[[Steal My Girl]]" and the piano melody of [[Journey (band)|Journey]]'s 1983 song "[[Faithfully (song)|Faithfully]]."<ref>{{cite news|author=Samantha Highfill|date=29 September 2014|title=One Direction channels Journey, gets dad-friendly with 'Steal My Girl'|url=http://music-mix.ew.com/2014/09/29/one-direction-steal-my-girl/|work=Entertainment Weekly|accessdate=29 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Mikael Wood|date=29 September 2014|title=Listen: One Direction journeys to the '80s in new song 'Steal My Girl'|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-listen-one-direction-turns-to-the-80s-in-new-single-steal-my-girl-20140929-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=29 September 2014}}</ref> *[[Meghan Trainor]] has been accused of lifting the melody from a 2006 song called "Happy Mode" by the Korean pop band Koyote, for her single "[[All About That Bass]]". Songwriter Joo Young Hoon has said he is consulting with a specialized lawyer.<ref>{{cite web|author=Tamar Herman|date=31 August 2014|title=Megan Trainor's Summer Hit 'All About That Bass' Sounds Suspiciously Like Koyote's 'Happy Mode'|url=http://www.kpopstarz.com/articles/106367/20140831/megan-trainors-all-about-that-bass-sounds-suspiciously-like-koyotes-happy-mode.htm|publisher=KpopStarz|accessdate=18 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Allkpop|date=27 August 2014|title=Composer Joo Young Hoon requests clarification from the composer of Meghan Trainor's 'All About That Bass' regarding possible plagiarism|url=http://www.allkpop.com/article/2014/08/composer-joo-young-hoon-requests-clarification-from-the-composer-of-meghan-trainors-all-about-that-bass-regarding-possible-plagiarism|publisher=6Theory Media|accessdate=18 September 2014}}</ref> *Following the "Blurred Lines" plagiarism verdict, members of [[Marvin Gaye]]'s family noted similarities between [[Pharrell Williams]]' award-winning hit single "[[Happy (Pharrell Williams song)|Happy]]" and Gaye's song "[[Ain't That Peculiar]]", written by [[Smokey Robinson]] and fellow [[The Miracles|Miracles]].<ref>{{cite news | title=Marvin Gaye's family claim Pharrell Williams' Happy sounds like ANOTHER one of the soul legend's songs | url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/marvin-gayes-family-claim-pharrell-5316275 | accessdate=12 March 2015 | last=Rutter | first=Claire | work=The Mirror | date=12 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title=Marvin Gaye’s Family Considering 'Happy' After 'Blurred Lines' Win | url=http://time.com/3741930/marvin-gaye-pharrell-happy/ | accessdate=12 March 2015 | last=Berenson | first=Tessa | work=Time | date=12 March 2015}}</ref> *In 2015, the web page of the Australian music TV channel [[MAX (Australian TV channel)|MAX]] published an article by music writer Nathan Jolly that noted similarities between [[Guns N' Roses]]' song "[[Sweet Child o' Mine]]" and the song "Unpublished Critics" by the Australian band [[Australian Crawl]], from 1981.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maxtv.com.au/news/how-similar-is-sweet-child-o-mine-to-a-1981-australian-crawl-song.aspx|title=MAX - Where Music Lives|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160619224146/http://www.maxtv.com.au/news/how-similar-is-sweet-child-o-mine-to-a-1981-australian-crawl-song.aspx|archivedate=19 June 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The article posted videos of both songs, inviting readers to compare the two. It also cited a reader's comment on an earlier article<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maxtv.com.au/news/slash-is-open-to-a-gunners-reunion-never-say-never.aspx|title=MAX - Where Music Lives|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160419011218/http://www.maxtv.com.au/news/slash-is-open-to-a-gunners-reunion-never-say-never.aspx|archive-date=19 April 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> that had originally drawn attention to the similarities between the songs. The story went "[[Viral marketing|viral]]"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://app.viralnewschart.com/News/News.aspx?linkId=108853839|title=Guns N Roses Sweet Child O Mine comes under plagiarism charges - ViralNewsChart via Consequence of Sound|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref> quickly, encouraging several comments on both the MAX article and the suggestion that the Australian song had influenced "Sweet Child o' Mine".<ref>http://www.news.com.au/entertainment/australian-crawl-fans-spark-online-debate-after-pointing-out-similarities-with-guns-n-roses-hit/story-e6frfmq9-1227350742310</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/6568203/guns-n-roses-sweet-child-o-mine-australian-crawl|title=Did Guns N' Roses Copy 'Sweet Child O' Mine' From This Australian Band?|publisher=|accessdate=6 October 2016}}</ref> *In July 2015, a lawsuit was launched against [[Rod Stewart]] by the heirs of blues singer [[Bo Carter|Armenter "Bo Carter" Chatmon]] alleging that "Corrina, Corrina", a track on Stewart's 2013 release ''[[Time (Rod Stewart album)|Time]]'', plagiarizes Chatmon's "[[Corrine, Corrina]]", which he wrote in 1928.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rod Stewart Slapped with Plagiarism Suit|url=http://wror.com/2015/07/06/rod-stewart-slapped-plagiarism-suit/|accessdate=27 July 2015|last=Graff|first=Gary|work=WROR News|date=6 July 2015}}</ref> *In November 2015, R&B musician Jesse Braham commenced a lawsuit against singer [[Taylor Swift]] over the similarities in lyrics between his 2013 single "Hater Gonna Hate" and Swift's 2014 hit "[[Shake It Off (Taylor Swift song)|Shake It Off]]".<ref>https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-34692465 Taylor Swift sued over Shake It Off lyrics</ref> Braham is seeking a writing credit and $42 million in damages.<ref>http://www.statepress.com/article/2015/11/copyright-laws-are-too-strict-for-artists Unknown artist sues Taylor Swift for $42 million, takes advantage of U.S. copyright laws</ref> *On 9 June 2016, it was revealed that English singer [[Ed Sheeran]] was being sued by songwriters [[Martin Harrington]] and Thomas Leonard, composers of [[Matt Cardle]]'s 2011 single "[[Amazing (Matt Cardle song)|Amazing]]", for $20 million for copyright infringement over Sheeran's 2015 single "[[Photograph (Ed Sheeran song)|Photograph]]". The lawsuit states: "Given the striking similarity between the chorus of 'Amazing' and 'Photograph', (the) defendants knew when writing, publishing, recording, releasing, and distributing 'Photograph' that they were infringing on a pre-existing musical composition."<ref name="lawsuit">{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/36486648/ed-sheeran-is-being-sued-for-20m-by-two-songwriters-over-his-track-photograph|title=Ed Sheeran is being sued for $20m by two songwriters over his track Photograph|date=9 June 2016|work=[[Newsbeat]]|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|accessdate=9 June 2016}}</ref> *The Led Zeppelin song "[[Black Mountain Side]]" sounds similar to [[Bert Jansch]]'s version of the traditional folk song "[[Down by Blackwaterside]]". No legal action was ever taken against Led Zeppelin, because it could not be proved that the recording in itself constituted Jansch's own copyright, as the basic melody is traditional.<ref name="Wall">[[Mick Wall]] (2008), ''When Giants Walked the Earth: A Biography of Led Zeppelin'', London: Orion, p. 56</ref> *A number of people have put forth the opinion that the introduction, and opening guitar arpeggios, of Led Zeppelin's "[[Stairway to Heaven]]" bears a close resemblance to the 1968 instrumental "[[Taurus (instrumental)|Taurus]]" by the group [[Spirit (band)|Spirit]].<ref>"Whammy Bar" ''[[Guitar World]]'' April 1997: 19 "But California's most enduring legacy may well be the fingerpicked acoustic theme of the song "Taurus," which Jimmy Page lifted virtually note for note for the introduction to "Stairway to Heaven."</ref> In May 2014 an attorney hired by [[Randy California]]'s estate announced plans to file a copyright infringement suit that will seek a co-writing credit for California on "Stairway to Heaven." <ref>Los Angeles Times, May 21, 2014</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Stairway to Heaven: The Song Remains Pretty Similar |author= |url= http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-05-15/led-zeppelins-stairway-to-heaven-vs-dot-spirits-taurus-a-reckoning|publisher=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]] |date=15 May 2014 |accessdate=21 May 2014}}</ref> A Los Angeles jury ruled in favor of Led Zeppelin in June 2016.<ref>{{cite web |title=Led Zeppelin Win "Stairway to Heaven" Trial |author= |url= http://pitchfork.com/news/65376-led-zeppelin-win-stairway-to-heaven-trial/ |date=23 June 2016 |accessdate=24 June 2016}}</ref> *Reviews of the song "[[Since I've Been Loving You]]" by Led Zeppelin (from their ''Led Zeppelin III'' album) have noted its similarity to the [[Moby Grape]] song "Never".<ref>http://www.allmusic.com/song/since-ive-been-loving-you-mt0003491422</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/readers-poll-the-best-led-zeppelin-songs-of-all-time-20121010/4-since-ive-been-loving-you-0826453|title=4. 'Since I've Been Loving You' Photo - Readers' Poll: The Best Led Zeppelin Songs of All Time|work=Rolling Stone}}</ref> No legal action is known to have been taken. *Indian Music composer [[Gopi Sunder|Gopi Sunder's]] song "Nam Ooru Bengaluru" [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9GUtsBv9KYE] used in the Bangalore Days (2014) is exactly the same as the single of [[Bryan Adams]].'s [[Reckless (Bryan Adams album)|Summer of '69 .]] In 2016 he used "Take you down"'' [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OVQstw1rjG8] or'' song #20, from [[Daniel Pemberton]]'s score for the Guy Ritchie movie "The man from U.N.C.L.E (2015)" in a movie trailer of Kali (2016) [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vJ72PkYYZHs] . *The copyright status of "[[We Shall Overcome]]" has been disputed. A lawsuit argues that the song is in the public domain, as it stemmed from an earlier tune "We Will Overcome".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Graham |first1=David A. |title=Who Owns 'We Shall Overcome'? |url= https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2016/04/we-shall-overcome-lawsuit/478068/ |website=The Atlantic |accessdate=22 December 2016}}</ref> *Singer-songwriter Richard Morrill is suing singer [[Gwen Stefani]], her company Harajuku Lovers, [[Pharrell Williams]] and Interscope Records, claiming their single "Spark the Fire" infringes on his rights in a 1996 song he wrote called "Who's Got My Lightah."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cullens |first1=Ashley |title=Gwen Stefani & Pharrell Williams Accused of Copying 'Spark the Fire' Chorus |url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7655229/gwen-stefani-pharrell-williams-accused-copying-spark-the-fire |website=Billboard |accessdate=16 January 2017}}</ref> *Welsh rock band [[Lostprophets]] claimed that they originally wrote and performed the song "[[I Knew You Were Trouble]]" before it became a hit for [[Taylor Swift]].<ref>http://exclaim.ca/music/article/taylor_swift_returns_to_spotify_as_lostprophets_song</ref>
==See also== *[[Plagiarism detection]] *[[Contrafact]] *[[Credit (creative arts)]] *[[List of musical medleys]] *[[Mashup (music)]] *[[Musical quotation]] *[[Parody music]] *[[Potpourri (music)]] *[[Quodlibet]] *[[Source criticism#Source criticism in the arts|Source criticism in the arts]] *[[Variation (music)]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.arttimesjournal.com/music/mathematical.htm A Mathematical Look at Musical Plagiarism] by Frank Behrens, ''Art Times'', May 2004 *[http://cip.law.ucla.edu/ UCLA Law Copyright Infringement Project] *J. Michael Keyes, "Musical Musings: The Case for Rethinking Music Copyright Protection", 10 Mich. Telecomm. Tech. L. Rev. 407 (2004), available at [https://web.archive.org/web/20080820054630/http://www.mttlr.org/volten/Keyes.pdf] *L. McDonagh, "Is Creative use of Musical Works without a licence acceptable under Copyright?" International Review of Intellectual Property and Competition Law (IIC) 4 (2012) 401-426, available at [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2521081 SSRN]
{{Appropriation in the Arts}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Musical Plagiarism}} [[Category:Plagiarism|*]] [[Category:Sampling]]
